facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 219 of 1960 filed by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal A peal No. 219 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal against judgment and order dated January 7, 1960 of Punjab High Court Circuit Bench at Delhi in Criminal Appeal No. 45-D of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 7, 1960, of the Punjab High Court  Circuit Bench  at Delhi, in Criminal Appeal No. 45-D of 1959.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on March 21, 1963 by Subba Rao J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 21. The judgment of the Court was delivered by SUBBA RAO. J.-This appeal by special leave is against the judgment

facts.text: High Court confirmed conviction by Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi under s.467 IPC with sentence of imprisonment till rising of Court and fine Rs.250.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal by special leave is against the judgment and order of the High Court of Punjab, Circuit Bench, Delhi, confirming those of the Additional Sessions judge, Delhi, convicting the appellant under s. 467 of the Indian Penal Code and sentencing him to imprisonment till the rising of the Court and to a fine of Rs. 250/-

facts.text: Appellant is Under Secretary under suspension in Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi, and son of Janki Pershad.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is an Under Secretary, under suspension, in the Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi, and is the son of janki Pershad.

facts.text: Janki Pershad held a ration depot in Delhi.

anchor.surface_text: janki Pershad held a ration depot in Delhi.

facts.text: In 1948, Janki Pershad purchased three Post Office National Savings Certificates of Rs.250 each in name of Controller of Rationing, Delhi, deposited as security.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1948 janki Pershad purchased three Post Office National Savings Certificates of the face value of Rs. 250/-in the name of the Controller or Rationing, Delhi, and deposited the same with him as security.

facts.text: On February 21, 1952, Janki Pershad transferred ration depot to his grandson S.K. Bansal, son of appellant.

anchor.surface_text: On February 21, 1952, Janki Pershad transferred the ration depot in favour of his grandson, S. K. Bansal, the son of the appellant.

facts.text: On April 16, 1952, Janki Pershad applied to rationing authority for release of security as depot transferred to grandson who gave fresh cash security.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, on April 16, 1952, janki Pershad applied to the rationing authority for the release of the said security on the ground that he had transferred the concerned ration depot in favour of his grandson who had given a fresh cash security of his own.

facts.text: Janki Pershad died on June 1, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Before the said security given by him was released, janki Pershad died on June 1, 1952.

facts.text: On July 1, 1952, rationing authority wrote to Janki Pershad (unaware of death) that security released and sent form for transfer of certificates to his name.

anchor.surface_text: On July 1, 1952, the ration- ing authority wrote a letter to janki Pershad, not knowing that he had died, informing him that the security deposited by him had been released and that he should get the pledged certificates transferred in his favour by filling in the prescribed form sent with that letter and presenting the same along with the certificates returned at the post office.

facts.text: Appellant filled the form for transfer, signed purporting to be father's signature, attested it, affixed Ministry stamp, presented form and certificates at Post Office.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution case is that, as janki Prashad had by that time died, the appellant filled in the said form for transfer, affixed the signature purporting it to be that of his father, attested the said signature, and affixed the stamp of Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, beneath his own signature of attestation, and presented the said form and the certificates at the Post Office.

facts.text: Post Office issued fresh certificates in name of Janki Pershad on July 12, 1952 after assurance by appellant despite clerk's doubts.

anchor.surface_text: Though the clerk at the Post Office had some doubts as to the genuineness of the signature of Janki Pershad, on an assurance given by the appellant, he issued fresh certificates in the name of Janki Pershad on July 12, 1952.

facts.text: On September 3, 1952, appellant signed three certificates on back as Janki Pershad, attested with stamp, gave letter of authority to Bhawani Shankar to cash them.

anchor.surface_text: On September 3, 1952, the appellant signed the three certificates on their back as janki Pershad in token of their cancellation and placed his own attestation and stamp of his office thereon. He gave a letter of authority in favour of Bhawani Shankar, a daftri attached to his Office, for cashing the same.

facts.text: Bhawani Shankar presented certificates at Post Office, received Rs.275, amount paid to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Bhawani Shankar presented the certificates at the Post Office and received Rs. 275/- in payment thereof, on his furnishing the necessary receipts The encashed amount was paid to the appellant.

facts.text: On September 8, 1956, Magistrate First Class Delhi framed charges under s.467 IPC and committed to Sessions.

anchor.surface_text: On September 8, 1956, the Magistrate, First Class, Delhi, framed charges against the appellant under s. 467 of the Indian Penal Code and committed him for trial before the Court of Sessions.

facts.text: On February 2, 1959, Additional Sessions Judge Delhi convicted appellant under s.467 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: On February 2, 1959, the Additional Sessions judge, Delhi, found him guilty under s. 467 of the Indian Penal Code and sentenced him as aforesaid.

facts.text: Appellant denied forging signatures, going to Post Office, deputing Bhawani Shankar, and disowned his attestations and stamps.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied that he forged the signature of his father in the application, in the certificates or in the letter of authority. He also denied to have gone to the Post Office and got the fresh certificates, or to have deputed Bhawani Shankar for encashment of the said certificates. Further, he disowned his own signature of attestation of the alleged signature of Janki pershad and denied to have affixed his office stamp on any of them.

facts.text: Additional Sessions Judge held both charges substantiated and convicted under s.467 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Additional Sessions judge, after considering the entire evidence placed before him, held that both the charges had been substantiated and therefore found the appellant guilty under s. 467 of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: High Court found appellant forged signature on application form but clearly attested it; forged signatures on certificates and letter of authority.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, Chopra J., reviewed the entire evidence over again and came to the conclusion that though it had not been established that the, signature on the application form was forged by the appellant, there was a clear and convincing evidence that the appellant attested the same. On the second charge, the learned Judge found that the alleged signatures of janki Pershad on the back of the three certificates and the writting of the signature on the letter of authority were all forged by the appellant.

facts.text: Supreme Court accepts concurrent findings that appellant put father's signature on documents, attested them, got securities transferred and received money.

anchor.surface_text: There are, therefore, concurrent findings of fact that the appellant put the signature of his father on the relevant documents, attested them and got the securities transferred in the name of his father and received the money from the Post Office. The said findings being findings of fact based upon relevant evidence, following the usual practice of this Court, we accept them.

facts.text: Appellant contends he is not guilty of forgery as sole heir receiving due money, no gain or injury.

anchor.surface_text: Even so, Mr. Chari, learned counsel for the appellant, contends that on the said findings the appellant is not guilty of forgery as defined under s. 464 of the Indian Penal Code, for, it is said, he received the money which was admittedly due to him as a sole heir of his father and, therefore, he did. not either gain an advantage for himself or cause any injury to another

facts.text: To encash certificates of deceased holder valued under Rs.5000, heir can declare sole heir after 3 months from death.

anchor.surface_text: if the current value of the certificates at the time of the death of the holder does not exceed Rs. 5,000/- he can, after the expiry of three months from the date of the death of the holder, satisfy the Post Master General that he is the sole heir of the holder and after making the relevant declaration recover the said money.

Delhi, convicting the appellant under s. 467 of the Indian Penal Code and sentencing him to imprisonment till the rising of the Court

The said findings being findings of fact based upon relevant evidence, following the usual practice of this Court, we accept them.

The said findings being findings of fact based upon relevant evidence, following the usual practice of this Court, we accept them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent findings of lower courts based on relevant evidence accepted per usual Supreme Court practice.

holdings.text: A person, therefore, will be guilty of forgery if he dishonestly or fraudulently signs a document with the intention mentioned in s. 464 of the Code.

anchor.surface_text: A person, therefore, will be guilty of forgery if he dishonestly or fraudulently signs a document with the intention mentioned in s. 464 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of ss. 463 and 464 IPC: forgery requires dishonest or fraudulent making of false document with specified intent.

holdings.text: On the said facts we have no doubt that the appellant had made the false documents with an intention to cause wrongful gain to himself, for by adopting the aforesaid device he secured for himself a gain as otherwise he would have had to incur some expense for obtaining a succession certificate.

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts we have no doubt that the appellant had made the false documents with an intention to cause wrongful gain to himself, for by adopting the aforesaid device he secured for himself a gain as otherwise he would have had to incur some expense for obtaining a succession certificate. Even on the assumption that he would have received the money after satisfying the rationing authority and the Post Master General, he secured an advantage by resorting to the said device, as he was relieved of the trouble of satisfying the rationing authority and the postal authority that he was the sole heir of his father and avoided the risk of their refusal, which would have entailed further delay.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant acted dishonestly u/s 24 IPC by intending wrongful gain (saving expense and trouble of succession certificate or waiting period) and fraudulently u/s 25 by short-circuiting legal procedures.

holdings.text: In either case he committed forgery, within the meaning of s. 463 of the Indian Penal Code.

anchor.surface_text: In either case he committed forgery, within the meaning of s. 463 of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: False documents made dishonestly or fraudulently constitute forgery under s. 463 IPC even if no injury to another but wrongful gain to self.

holdings.text: The decision of this Court in Dr. Vimla's case, is clearly distinguishable from the present case.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in Dr. Vimla's case, is clearly distinguishable from the present case. In Dr. Vimla's case, this Court, after considering the relevant decisions on the question, stated the legal position thus The expression defraud involves two elements, namely, deceit and injury to the person deceived.

holdings.reasoning_summary: In Dr. Vimla, no economic or non-economic advantage to deceiver or loss to deceived; here, appellant gained economic advantage (saved expense) and non-economic (avoided trouble).

holdings.text: He was, therefore, guilty of making the false documents both dishonestly and fraudulently.

anchor.surface_text: He was, therefore, guilty of making the false documents both dishonestly and fraudulently.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Intent to defraud satisfied as benefit to deceiver (wrongful gain via deceit) constitutes injury; applies ss. 24, 25 IPC.

holdings.text: The High Court is right in coming to the conclusion which it did.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court is right in coming to the conclusion which it did.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court's confirmation of conviction under s. 467 IPC based on above legal determinations.

Mr. Anthony, learned companynsel appearing for the State, does number accept either the factual or the legal position advanced by the learned companynsel for the appellant. He companytends that on the facts found, the appellant, when he put the signatures of his father on the relevant documents, had the clear intention to secure an economic advantage to himself inasmuch as he resorted to the device adopted by him in order to save himself the trouble and expense of obtaining a succession certificate.

precedents.case_name: Dr. Vimla v. The Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: the said point was directly and fully covered by the case, namely that receiving money due as sole heir by forging father's signature does not amount to forgery as no gain to self or injury to another

anchor.surface_text: Dr, Vimla s case  1 , to the facts of the present case can be better appreciated if the facts of the resent case are clearly borne in mind. If a person who has given postal certificates as security to a department by taking them in the name of the said department dies, his heir can get the said amount by following two procedures, namely,  1  after obtaining a succession certificate, he can apply to the department companycerned to release the security and then apply to the postal department for getting the certicates cashed, and  2  if the current value of the certificates at the time of the death of the holder does number exceed Rs. 5,000/- he can, after the expiry of three months from the date of the death of the holder, satisfy the Post Master General that he is the sole heir of the holder and after making the relevant

precedents.case_name: Dr. Vimla v. The Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: application of the case to the facts of the present case

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Vimlas case  1 , is clearly distinguishable from the present case. In Dr. Vimlas case  1 , this Court, after companysidering the relevant decisions on the question, stated the legal position thus The expression defraud involves two elements, namely, deceit and injury to the person deceived. Injury is something other than economic loss, that is, deprivation of property, whether movable or immovable, or of Money, and it will include any harm whatever caused to any person in body, mind, reputation or such others. In short, it is a number- economic or number-pecuniary loss. A benefit or advantage to the deceiver will almost always cause loss or detriment to the deceived.

precedents.case_name: Dr. Vimla v. The Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: the case is clearly distinguishable from the present case

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Vimlas case  1 , this Court, after companysidering the relevant decisions on the question, stated the legal position thus The expression defraud involves two elements, namely, deceit and injury to the person deceived. Injury is something other than economic loss, that is, deprivation of property, whether movable or immovable, or of Money, and it will include any harm whatever caused to any person in body, mind, reputation or such others. In short, it is a number- economic or number-pecuniary loss. A benefit or advantage to the deceiver will almost always cause loss or detriment to the deceived. Even in those rare cases where there is a benefit or advantage to the deceiver, but numbercorresponding loss to the deceived, the second companydition is satisfied.

precedents.case_name: Dr. Vimla v. The Delhi Administration
precedents.cited_proposition: expression defraud involves deceit and injury to the deceived; injury not limited to economic loss; no forgery where no injury even if benefit to deceiver, as in facts of signing as minor daughter for insurance claim with no loss to insurer
precedents.cited_holding: she was number guilty of forgery

anchor.surface_text: relevant  1  1963 Supp, 2 S.C.R, 585. declaration recover the said money. In one case he has to incur expenses for obtaining the succession certificate and in the other lie has to wait for three months and thereafter produce evidence to the satisfaction of the Post Master General that he is the sole heir of the deceased holder of the certificates. In the present case, the appellant attested the signature of janki Pershad on the reverse of the application form, for the transfer of the Post Office National Savings Certificates in the name of his father, got fresh certificates issued in the name of his father, signed the name of Janki Pershad on the back of the three certi- ficates in token of their cancellation, placed his own attestation and stamp of his office thereon, gave a letter of authority in favour of Bhawani Shanker as though it was given by janki Pershad and received the money from the Post Office.

anchor.surface_text: the money which  1  1963 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 585. he would have otherwise spent in obtaining a succession certificate, and  ii  getting the money belonging to his father as his heir. He was, therefore, guilty of making the false documents both dishonestly and fraudulently. The High Court is right in companying to the companyclusion which it did.

anchor.surface_text: There are, therefore, concurrent findings of fact that the appellant put the signature of his father on the relevant documents, attested them and got the securities transferred in the name of his father and received the money from the Post Office. The said findings being findings of fact based upon relevant evidence, following the usual practice of this Court, we accept them.

anchor.surface_text: On the said facts we have no doubt that the appellant had made the false documents with an intention to cause wrongful gain to himself, for by adopting the aforesaid device he secured for himself a gain as otherwise he would have had to incur some expense for obtaining a succession certificate. Even on the assumption that he would have received the money after satisfying the rationing authority and the Post Master General, he secured an advantage by resorting to the said device, as he was relieved of the trouble of satisfying the rationing authority and the postal authority that he was the sole heir of his father and avoided the risk of their refusal, which would have entailed further delay.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of this Court in Dr. Vimla's case, is clearly distinguishable from the present case.
